Award.AwardTitle: Computing Partition Functions in Hard Problems of Combinatorial Enumeration and Optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Problems of combinatorial optimization concern finding the optimal value of a function defined on a finite, though very large, set. Such problems have many real world applications and, for the most part, are notoriously difficult to solve, because the set of possible solutions is prohibitively large. The P.I. intends to investigate such problems through the approach of partition functions, the method inspired to a large extent by statistical physics. This will lead to new efficient algorithms in previously intractable problems.

The particular problems addressed by the project include efficient computation of partition functions associated with perfect matching in (hyper)graphs, Hamiltonian cycles and cliques in graphs, graph homomorphisms, and systems of multivariate real quadratic equations. It will allow one to identify efficiently solvable cases of hard problems. For example, one will be able to efficiently distinguish graphs with sufficiently many (but still hard to find) Hamiltonian cycles from graphs that are sufficiently far away from Hamiltonian.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partition functions encode complicated combinatorial structures in a closed form. Computing partition functions efficiently is important in problems of discrete optimization, computer science and statistical physics. The main achievement of the project is a new approach that relates the computational complexity of approximation of partition functions to their complex zeros: it is based on the observation that a multivariate polynomial can be efficiently approximated in a complex domain provided it has no zeros in a slightly larger domain. This idea was successfully applied by the P.I. and other researchers to approximate permanents of matrices and tensors (responsible for counting perfect matchings in graphs and hypergraphs), for finding dense subgraphs of graphs, counting of independent sets in graphs, counting of graph colorings, for computing the partition function in the Potts and more general multi-spin models, and other problems of interest to combinatorics and statistical physics. The relation of the method to the Lee-Yang theory of phase transition in statistical physics was also explored. The results were published in a number of journal papers and in the monograph "Combinatorics and Complexity of Partition Functions" (Springer 2016). The results were popularized in a number of lectures and short courses aimed for researchers and graduate students, in particular in a series of three lectures "Complex zeros and algorithms in hard problems of combinatorial counting" at GaTech (February-March, 2018), two lectures "Computing partition functions by polynomial interpolation" at the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing (January 2019,  Geometry of Polynomials Boot Camp), a series of three lectures "Combinatorics, complexity and complex zeros of partition functions" at MIT (April 2019, Simons Lecture Series).The P.I. taught a graduate course on partition functions at the University of Michigan, and supervised graduate and undergraduate (Research Experience for Undergraduates) research on the topic.
